subject: dark matter
raw:
Axions. <[silence]> Weakly Interacting Massive Particles. <[silence]> Gravitational Lensing. <[silence]>

Dark matter is a form of matter that does not emit, absorb, or reflect light, making it invisible and detectable only through its gravitational effects. <[silence]> It constitutes approximately 27% of the universe's total mass and energy, yet its exact nature remains one of the most intriguing puzzles in modern astrophysics. <[silence]> Unlike ordinary matter, dark matter does not interact with electromagnetic forces, which is why it cannot be observed directly with telescopes. <[silence]> Instead, scientists infer its presence through the gravitational effects it exerts on visible matter, radiation, and the large-scale structure of the universe. <[silence]>

Several candidates have been proposed to explain dark matter. <[silence]> Among them are Weakly Interacting Massive Particles (WIMPs) and axions, both hypothesized to have properties that could account for the observed gravitational phenomena. <[silence]> Experiments are ongoing to detect these particles directly, using highly sensitive detectors buried deep underground to shield them from cosmic radiation. <[silence]> Despite extensive research, no definitive evidence for these particles has been found, leaving the true composition of dark matter an open question. <[silence]>

Gravitational lensing offers a method to study dark matter indirectly. <[silence]> This phenomenon occurs when the gravitational field of a massive object, such as a galaxy cluster, bends the light from a more distant object, like a quasar. <[silence]> By analyzing these distortions, astronomers can map the distribution of dark matter in the universe. <[silence]> These observations have provided compelling evidence for dark matter's existence and distribution, yet they also highlight the limitations of our current understanding. <[silence]>

Three related subjects are the cosmic microwave background, large-scale structure formation, and neutrino physics.
